blogs.title: Designing with Clarity

detail.t1: Clarity begins with intent—every pixel should serve understanding, removing visual noise so meaning comes through first.
detail.t2: We reduce choices per screen and group content by meaning, letting structure guide the next decision naturally.
detail.t5: Typography sets rhythm; spacing reinforces hierarchy, and consistent scales keep interfaces honest—{{red}}making clarity feel intentional on every screen{{/red}}.
detail.t6: Accessible contrast and strong focus styles build trust; sensible motion and readable lengths keep fatigue low.
detail.t7: Empty states teach and guide the next action, turning dead ends into micro-onboarding moments.
detail.t8: Copy should state outcomes, not destinations, so users always know what happens when they commit.
detail.t11: Design reviews focus on user outcomes, not decoration; we ask if the next step is obvious and safe.
detail.t12a: Document decisions so future changes stay aligned; a brief rationale and link to examples helps—{{red}}the decision record becomes the single source of truth{{/red}}.
detail.t12c: Tokens map Figma choices to CSS variables so names reflect purpose, not raw values.
detail.t12d: Consistency scales teams without slowing creativity by removing trivia from daily decisions.
detail.t15a: Measure success via completion and errors avoided; {{red}}favor outcomes over output{{/red}} and review targets monthly.
detail.t15b: Ship small, learn quickly, refine deliberately; insight beats certainty.
detail.t15c: Clarity is a habit formed by constraints and care, repeated release by release.

detail.callout: Clarity is a team sport—codify choices and stick to them.

blogs.title: Next.js App Router Basics

detail.t1: Think in layouts and nested routes for fast transitions, sharing shells to avoid re-rendering everything.
detail.t2: Keep server work on the server and ship less JS to clients; data close to components stays understandable.
detail.t5: Route handlers unify caching and validation while {{red}}turning cross-cutting concerns into composable utilities{{/red}}.
detail.t6: Stream primary content first; hydrate islands later so users see progress before interactivity lands.
detail.t7: Use metadata and revalidation per page need, aligning freshness with business value.
detail.t8: Co-locate data with UI for clear ownership, keeping boundaries predictable.
detail.t11: Prefer suspense where it aids orientation; placeholders should suggest real structure.
detail.t12a: Measure field performance, not just lab; {{red}}RUM catches the surprises that synthetic tests miss{{/red}}.
detail.t12c: Define cache boundaries that match content change to avoid stale illusions.
detail.t12d: Split bundles by route; avoid shared giants that couple unrelated features.
detail.t15a: Automate guardrails in CI to catch regressions, {{red}}failing fast before users ever feel it{{/red}}.
detail.t15b: Pick boring, reliable patterns; durability wins long-term.
detail.t15c: Small, clear code beats cleverness when teams rotate.

img2.caption: Choose revalidate windows by content freshness.

detail.callout: Push complexity to the server, not the browser.

blogs.title: Performance First

detail.t1: Define a performance budget on day one and defend it as features grow.
detail.t2: Every dependency must earn its bytes; lazy load what’s optional.
detail.t5: Images matter most—serve the right size and ratio; {{red}}optimize formats and set explicit dimensions to avoid CLS{{/red}}.
detail.t6: Preload key fonts; use swap to avoid FOIT and audit weights you truly need.
detail.t7: Reserve space to prevent CLS and keep interactions steady under load.
detail.t8: Prefer CSS over JS for simple effects to save main-thread time.
detail.t11: Audit third-party scripts regularly and kill the ones that no longer pay rent.
detail.t12a: Use RUM to see real devices and networks; {{red}}lab wins only matter when field data agrees{{/red}}.
detail.t12c: Skeletons should match final layout so users don’t lose position.
detail.t12d: Communicate delays with honest microcopy to maintain trust.
detail.t15a: Delete code; {{red}}removing work is the best optimization{{/red}}.
detail.t15b: Measure, iterate, repeat; treat speed as behavior, not a milestone.
detail.t15c: Fast feels trustworthy and invites exploration.

img3.caption: Dead code is silent but costly.

detail.callout: Speed is a product feature, not an afterthought.

detail.t12d: Contrast should meet AA at minimum across themes and images.
detail.t15a: Quality beats frequency; {{red}}publishing less can produce more results{{/red}}.
detail.t15b: Fewer, better posts win and are easier to maintain.

blogs.title: Accessibility AA Checklist

detail.t1: Accessibility is quality work, not an add-on, and it compounds over time.
detail.t2: Use landmarks, ordered headings, and visible focus so structure is perceivable.
detail.t5: Color is never the only signal; {{red}}pair it with icons or text cues{{/red}}.
detail.t6: Labels must be clear and persistent; placeholders are not labels.
detail.t7: Keyboard users complete every flow with sensible tabindex and traps avoided.
detail.t8: aria-live announces async updates so screen readers aren’t left behind.
detail.t11: Provide transcripts and alt text with context, not noise.
detail.t12a: Test with a screen reader weekly; {{red}}NVDA/VoiceOver will humble your assumptions{{/red}}.
detail.t12c: Check contrast against AA including hover and disabled states.
detail.t12d: Avoid motion that harms vestibular comfort; honor reduced motion.
detail.t15a: Inclusive by default scales best; {{red}}accessibility helps everyone{{/red}}.
detail.t15b: Make checks part of PRs so regressions don’t sneak in.
detail.t15c: Everyone benefits from accessible choices in the end.

img2.caption: Contrast is a baseline, not an aspiration.

detail.callout: Habits, not heroics, make products accessible.
